title: What should I teach my 3-year-old daughter? - Quora

response.answer_text: The three-year-old children's guidance includes five major areas of health, language, society, science and art. The main contents are as follows: Lifestyle habits: work and rest habits, eating habits, hygiene habitsExercise habits: exercise balance ability, movement coordination ability, sensitivity, learning other technical activities, enhance physical strength, enhance physical endurance, fine hand movement abilitySelf-protection capabilities : life self-care ability, safety knowledge instillation, safety sign recognition, simple self-help methodSocial adaptability: polite language, basic rules of interaction with people, social behavior rules, conflict resolution, social and cultural perceptionBasic Cognition: Common Animal and Plant Cognition, Common Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Cognition, Sensory Cognition, Body Organ Cognition, Vehicle Cognition, Common Infrastructure and Place CognitionLanguage enlightenment: listening ability, language expression ability, reading ability, cognition of common signs, writing enlightenment, Chinese character enlightenment, English enlightenmentScientific enlightenment: contact with nature, exploration ability, observation and classification ability, reasoning and analysis abilityMathematical enlightenment: cognition of shape of things, cognition of numbers, cognition of time, cognition of laws, application of mathematics, cognition of quantitative relations, cognition of spatial orientationArtistic enlightenment: exposure to human landscape, music enlightenment, art enlightenment, and appreciation of other works of art

Emotional He should learn that he is separate from his parents, and that he has a will and can assert it. (The “terrible twos” are developmentally important.) He should also have learned that no matter how much he asserts his will, his parents are CONSISTENTLY in charge, in control of themselves, and capable of protecting him. Gross motor He should have the ability to jump but probably doesn’t have skipping yet (hop on one leg, step, hop on the other leg, step). More: Gross Motor Preschool Milestones 3 years to 5 years - North Shore Pediatric Therapy Fine motor He should be able to manually move a crayon around but probably can’t stay within lines, even roughly (they’re “scribbles”). Girls often have faster fine-motor development. I hate the scare-headline, but here’s a good list: Fine Motor Skills Interpersonal He should definitely be able to play side-by-side, and should at 3 be able to have some interactions (like co-creating stories). He won’t likely be particularly subtle at getting people to do what he wants. He also will understand the “sharing” concept but will likely still find it extremely difficult, particularly when he’s uncomfortable. Cognitively He should understand shape (shape sorters) and relative size (he will not go down the bathtub drain), though the latter may be more recent or still developing — don’t scare him; they really don’t understand this until they understand relative sizes (“bigger”). Many kids understand sequence, so you can do counting and alphabet with those kids. Some kids understand how to attach a sound to a shape and can begin reading — but not many. He probably has favorite songs and stories (remembering sequence) and will be able to remember people over time — probably not six months, but probably at least a month if they’re familiar, and at least a few days or so if it’s a new person. He should have enough of a working vocabulary to understand more complex instructions like “softer, gently, quietly” but will definitely need help in self-control particularly when tired and hungry. “Inside/outside” behaviors — clumping them together, like outside we run around and scream, inside we use less energy — will be more or less understood, but again will need a lot of reminders. That said a 3 year old should have enough self control and cognitive capacity to avoid touching a stove, putting a fork in an electrical outlet, or pulling things off the counter top. What I would work on: Plenty of physical expression. Their bodies are in hyperdrive. Gross motor when there’s space and you can supervise; fine motor when they need “quiet time.” And be patient training “sit still.” (Give yourself 12 cups of coffee, and then “sit still”!)Assess where he is in sequence and count together and say or sing the alphabet together (they love that). They’ll make mistakes, it’s ok; you’re just getting them used to sequences. You can see if they can accept a “B” makes a “buh” sound but that’s likely not going to be interesting for them as much as gross and fine motor mastery, which they’re much more driven towards, so don’t do that unless they’re pushing for it. You can count by twos if your kids are particularly adept at counting (and/or you’re bored), and movement helps memory, so this game is great for stairs, walking around the block, jumping…Sharing. Sharing when tired. Sharing a favored thing. Sharing a substitute item because they just can’t part with their favorite thing. Saying how they feel about sharing. Saying what they feel about pretty much anything. Note they will really not have much vocabulary for this unless the family explicitly talks about how they feel a lot, and a lot of the time, hearing parents say they feel scared or angry is utterly overwhelming to kids… so they probably will not have a way to express that unless you help them directly.Role playing games. Dress up. This is important for empathy development. Let them be the cat, the neighbor, the parent, the kid at school who bugs them so much…

How to be polite:  Please, Thank You, Sorry.  Those initial social skills are so important with all social interactions, because they're the foundation of understanding how you affect those around you.How to play:  Kids develop an imagination around then.  Play with them.  Join in.  Encourage that creativity.How to trust you:  You will always be there.  To keep her safe, to scare the shadows away, to comfort her when she's in pain.  That makes her feel safe and protected.How to talk to you:  Communication is one of the biggest social skills there is.  Teach her names for her emotions.  "Are you scared?" "Do you hurt?" "Are you mad?" "Are you happy?"  Little kids scream when they don't have the tools to express themselves any other way.  By teaching her how to name what she's feeling, you can validate how she feels and help to fix/understand it.  You have to really listen to her.How to share:  I'm working on this out with my son currently.  There is a social contract between kids that they have to learn.  But it's a really important thing to learn and understand early on.  You can demonstrate on a daily basis.In summary:  The most important thing you can teach her is how to interact with other people.  The earlier she learns that, the more successful she will be.

A2A 3 years is too early to teach her anything. I don't think I learnt anything at that age.     Teach :  That crying doesn't her buy anything. Teach her to speak little words (no signs), if they do not know what's something is called tell them and make them repeat the word, teach them to ask and request but not cry. I laugh hard when my niece cries.A trick if have been playing of late to keep my 3 year old niece shut is by pulling my mobile and saying her that I'd take a pic of her crying face and put it up on computer/facebook/to their teachers at the kindergarden. :)The importance of personal hygiene. Make it a habit that she washes her hands regularly.Sweet little things like thank you, welcome and I'm sorry. Turns her compassionate to people and surroundings. She learns from you. Thank the auto driver after your trip, the one who holds the door at the restaurant and if you are from India, make it a point to show dignity of labor atleast when she's around. Good sleeping habits. Your names, city, designation, office names. Possibly your home address too. When you roam out show her a police and how to identify one and tell her he's a good guy.Above all, make her believe that her dad is a super hero. Strive to be one.

About food and animals (as per basic education). Nothing else apart from personal hygiene and family members. Stop showing TV and giving cellphones to them. Let them build their own toys with mud, sand, clay anything they wish from the resources in front of them. Let them become smart in their own way and not by forcing into studies in such a young age. Do not compare with other families and start treating your child. Each one are unique and they just started exploring this world. Don't make them to continue the same mistakes as adult we did it. This is the second chance we get through them to correct those mistake of not being yourself.

Hopefully his name and names of his parents. Otherwise, unless a child is an outright genius, the kid should be playing with sand and toys. If you need a reference, you can ask your parents to pull out your own childhood album/stories and see what development is all about. If you have money and desire, invest in a specialized assessment of your son; or you can save that money and use it for something more fun such as an outing for the family. That is if your kid is already potty-trained and out of diapers.

Personally, this is what I would like my 4 year olds to know:  That they are loved unconditionally. To say please, thank you and sorry when needed. To be kind and gentle. To be brave enough to ask for help when they sense danger but not brave enough to think they can cross the road alone. That they can tell me anything at anytime of the day or night.

How to take risks and jump in puddles. How to bang pots and make noise and laugh loudly. They should also begin to understand how to treat others as co-equals but that often takes a bit longer. They should always be nice to animals.
How to kick a soccer ball. How to throw a baseball. How to ice skate. Those motor skills are important.
